item.title: 1 Introduction and foundations
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: A brief introduction to the course, preview of things to come, and some foundational background material.

item.title: 2 Linear regression
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Reviewing linear regression and framing it as a prototypical example and source of intuition for other machine learning methods.

item.title: 3 Interpreting regression and causality
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Multiple linear regression does not, by default, tell us anything about causality. But with the right data and careful interpretation we might be able to learn some causal relationships.

item.title: 4 Classification
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Categorical or qualitative outcome variables are ubiquitous. We review some supervised learning methods for classification, and see how these may be applied to observational causal inference.

item.title: 5 Optimization and model complexity
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Machine learning is broadly about estimating functions using optimization algorithms. We can think of these as searching through a space of functions to find one that minimizes a measure of inaccuracy or loss.

item.title: 6 Regularization and validation
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: When optimizing an ML model there are a variety of strategies to improve generalization from the training data. We can add a complexity penalty to the loss function, and we can evaluate the loss function on validation data.

item.title: 7 High-dimensional regression
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Regression with many predictor variables can suffer from a statistical version of the curse of dimensionality. Penalized regression methods like ridge and lasso are useful in such high-dimensional settings.

item.title: 8 Additive non-linearity
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: We continue our exploration of non-linear supervised machine learning approaches including tree based methods, GAMs, and neural networks and graphs structured learning.

item.title: 8 More nonlinear methods
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: We continue our exploration of non-linear supervised machine learning approaches including tree based methods, GAMs, and neural networks and graphs structured learning.

item.title: 9 Less interpretable methods
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Neural networks and ensemble methods like bagging, random forests, and boosting can greatly increase predictive accuracy at the cost of ease of interpretation.

item.title: 10 From prediction to action
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Supervised machine learning methods excel at predicting an outcome. But being able to predict an outcome does not mean we know how to change it, or that we should.

item.title: 11 To the future
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Some resources for learning more and suggestions on what to study next.
